H3.text: what are the three official languages of belgium. Dutch Language

A4.text: Belgium officially recognizes Dutch, French, and German as its three official languages.

A5.text: Dutch is an official language of the Netherlands proper (not enshrined in the constitution but in administrative law), Belgium, Suriname, the Dutch Caribbean municipalities (St. Eustatius, Saba and Bonaire), Aruba, Cura√ßao and Sint Maarten.

A6.text: three of the four language areas into which the country is divided (Flanders, francophone Wallonia, and the German-speaking Community) are largely monolingual, with Brussels being bilingual.

A7.text: In Belgium, French is an official language at the federal level along with Dutch and German.

A8.text: French is an official language at the federal level in Belgium along with Dutch and German.

A9.text: German is an official language of Luxembourg, Belgium and the Italian autonomous province of South Tyrol.

A10.text: Belgium has three official languages: Dutch, French and German.

A11.text: An estimated 60% of the Belgian population are native speakers of Dutch (often referred to as Flemish), and 40% of the population speaks French natively.
